items.content_html:
Partially fixes #27789 by using matching devices found in /dev/disk/by-label/* before using any found in /dev/disk/by-uuid/*.

Wil T's install tutorial explains the motivation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=axOxLJ4BWmY&t=1295s

Description of changes

This doesn't change any packages; only newly generated hardware configurations are affected.

This does NOT fix #27789 as originally reported (I was not able to repro that myself), but does address this comment.

At some point the automatic detection of device labels broke and device UUIDs began taking precedent over labels. This makes setting up a new computer a more manual and error-prone process than it needs to be.

With this change, I can instead use the devices generated as-is in hardware-configuration.nix on reinstall.

17) Gibraltar		 34) North Macedonia
#? 47

The following information has been given:

	Switzerland
	B√ºsingen

Therefore TZ='Europe/Zurich' will be used.
Selected time is now:	Tue Dec  5 15:24:52 CET 2023.
Universal Time is now:	Tue Dec  5 14:24:52 UTC 2023.

You can make this change permanent for yourself by appending the line

to the file '.profile' in your home directory; then log out and log in again.

can use the /run/current-system/sw/bin/tzselect command in shell scripts:

It's not great how it says to set it in .profile, but the NixOS docs should be obvious that it should be set to time.timeZone.

items.content_html:
New installs should use better maintained modules, so it becomes easier
to deprecated older ones, since hopefully fewer people will rely on them.

Instead of relying on the bespoke networking module options for DHCP,
let's generate two networkd profiles, that provide DHCP and
accept Router Advertisements on Ethernet and WLAN interfaces.

Networkd processes profiles alphanumerically and one interface can only
ever be matched to a single profile. Creating more specific profiles with
lower numbering will therefore supersede these profiles.

Is this controversial?

Hopefully not. We ship with systemd-networkd on every system anyway, and it receives far better maintenance than our very own networking module stack.

Is this finished?

Highly unlikely.

  • What is the consensus about the default network configuration?
    • Did I replicate that correctly?
    • How many comments should it contain?
    • What documentation can we reference?
  • Disabling useDHCP can't possible be this simple.
    • How do we get network on the ISOs?
    • Which tests implicitely rely on useDHCP?
    • This is most probably a breaking change and needs a broader announcement

Is this tested?

Nope, not yet.

  • Running the installer tests right now

Open questions

  • Can the nixos-generate-config changes be landed without the useDHCP changes?
    • in which case we'd probably have to ship with networking.useDHCP = false; for some time

items.content_html:
systemd-analyze security sshd with default settings currently summarises as follows:

Overall exposure level for sshd.service: 9.6 UNSAFE üò®"

This PR moves that up to "5.3 MEDIUM :-|".

To do:

  • RootDirectory=/RootImage= Service runs within the host's root directory 0.1
  • SupplementaryGroups= Service runs as root, option does not matter
  • RemoveIPC= Service runs as root, option does not apply
  • User=/DynamicUser= Service runs as root user
  • NoNewPrivileges= Service processes may acquire new privileges
  • PrivateDevices= Service potentially has access to hardware devices
  • ProtectClock= Service may write to the hardware clock or system clock
  • ProtectKernelLogs= Service may read from or write to the kernel log ring buffer
  • ProtectControlGroups= Service may modify the control group file system
  • ProtectKernelModules= Service may load or read kernel modules
  • PrivateMounts= Service may install system mounts
  • MemoryDenyWriteExecute= Service may create writable executable memory mappings
  • RestrictSUIDSGID= Service may create SUID/SGID files
  • ProtectHostname= Service may change system host/domainname
  • ProtectKernelTunables= Service may alter kernel tunables
  • RestrictAddressFamilies=~AF_UNIX Service may allocate local sockets
  • RestrictAddressFamilies=~‚Ä¶ Service may allocate exotic sockets
  • RestrictAddressFamilies=~AF_(INET|INET6) Service may allocate Internet sockets
  • RestrictRealtime= Service may acquire realtime scheduling
  • DeviceAllow= Service has no device ACL
  • ProtectSystem= Service has full access to the OS file hierarchy
  • ProtectProc= Service has full access to process tree (/proc hidepid=)
  • ProcSubset= Service has full access to non-process /proc files (/proc subset=)
  • ProtectHome= Service has full access to home directories
  • CapabilityBoundingSet=~CAP_NET_(BIND_SERVICE|BROADCAST|RAW) Service has elevated networking privileges
  • PrivateNetwork= Service has access to the host's network
  • PrivateUsers= Service has access to other users
  • PrivateTmp= Service has access to other software's temporary files
  • IPAddressDeny= Service does not define an IP address allow list
  • UMask= Files created by service are world-readable by default

Recommended settings which are not part of this PR because they broke nix-build -A nixosTests.openssh:

While far from perfect this offers some guidance for setting up a cluster with Ceph. It is intentionally not a step-by-step guide however. The NixOS Tests can fill the gap of a step-by-step guide, however upstream documentation and recommendations may change. If for instance the permissions required by a service such as an MGR ever tighten in the upstream documentation it would be great if users used that updated upstream documentation even if the tests have not caught on.

I recently helped a user trying to install nixos via the NIXOS_LUSTRATE method described in the manual, who ran into some rather glaring issues, which have apparently existed for an embarassingly long time without being addressed (#49520), so I took it upon myself to improve the situation.

  • Altered switch-to-configuration.pl so that when the action is boot, it does not complain when /run/current-system/sw/bin does not exist.
  • Rewrote the main install step of the relevant section of the manual to:
    • Include the necessary NIXOS_INSTALL_BOOTLOADER variable
    • Alter the backup mechanism used in the code block to correctly handle cases where /boot is a mount point
    • Explain enough to hopefully handle cases where the given commands won't work verbatim

Closes #49520.

Note that I have not actually tested these instructions, and that should definitely happen before merge, but from second-hand reports, it should be correct... hopefully.

items.content_html:
Improving NixOS Zapret module.

Now that #347805 got merged, which contained basic implementation, it's time to discuss possible QoL and functionality improvements. I'll draw some ideas bellow, yet I'm open to suggestions.

Again, those are just ideas to discuss. Or just leave the module as is to keep it simple?

Better http processing.

Current implementation bypasses DPI that only tracks first packet within keep-alive session. It is fast, as it only requires processing of a single packet. But there are scenarios when DPI tracks all the packets. This needs a different approach of processing every packet. Should be slower in theory, tho I haven't tested it yet.

Straightforward solution is just to create an option for that. But I'm unsure as that'd either be dull "enable this if http doesn't work" or a description that is a bit too technical for the end user.

UDP support.

Discord was blocked in Russia recently and it uses UDP for RTC. Zapret (nfqws) supports UDP even tho configuration is much more complicated. Only issue with that now is the fact that Discord works fine for me. Which means that I need to do a field operation of testing on a public WiFi or someone else testing that for me. I prepared a draft of possible configuration. I am also not aware of any other blocked services that use UDP.

Pre-configured targets.

Not a great idea. Not universal and requires too much maintenance. Result doesn't worth the effort.

This is purely QoL, but it might be nice to have options for specific services, like Youtube, which could be enabled like that: 
services.zapret = {
  enable = true;
  target = {
    youtube.enable = true;
    discord.enable = true;
  };
};

It really should be called whitelist.<target> but I take the shame for missing that opportunity. Still it'd work as a whitelist by adding known domains to the whitelist - this does not include setting up params option (but might require enabling not yet available udpSupport option, which would likely append stuff to params). This solves the problem of finding all required domains for the service, i.e. Youtube requires 4 domains that are listed in whitelist example. But it introduces the problem of maintaining such lists.
The only issue I see is that it might not be universal for everyone, but still should cover most cases.

An alternative would be creating a Wiki page.

items.content_html:
bonsai project.

nixpkgs already has the package for bonsai, which is only usable as a client + daemon setup. until now, bonsai package users were presumably all configuring their own services. this provides that service component, generally.

i chose to implement this as a user service. that's because both the daemon and client components -- bonsaid and bonsaictl coordinate on a socket by using the XDG_RUNTIME_DIR environment variable. so, if either one is invoked by a different user, they fail to connect. one can't run bonsaid as root and bonsaictl as an ordinary user, for example. the only thing that made sense was to attach bonsaid to the user's service manager.

@MatthewCroughan has graciously agreed to test this module.
